title: 109_hr2070
content: The Gas Price Spike Act of 2005, also known as the Windfall Profits Tax, imposes a tax on crude oil, natural gas, and related products under a new chapter in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Gas Price Spike Act of 2005, known as the Windfall Profits Tax, imposes an excise tax on the sale of crude oil, natural gas, or other taxable products in the US based on the windfall profit exceeding a reasonable profit percentage. The Windfall Profits Tax imposes taxes on the sale of certain products based on profit percentages exceeding reasonable levels, determined by the Reasonable Profits Board. Sellers are liable for payment of these taxes. The section discusses the windfall profit on crude oil and refined petroleum products, with effective amendments taking place upon enactment. Additionally, it introduces a credit for purchasing fuel-efficient American-made passenger vehicles under section 25C of the Internal Revenue Code. The tax code allows individuals a credit for purchasing qualified passenger vehicles, with maximum credits of $3,000, $4,500, or $6,000 based on fuel economy. The tax code provides credits for purchasing qualified passenger vehicles, with maximum credits of $3,000, $4,500, or $6,000 based on fuel economy. A qualified passenger vehicle must meet specific fuel economy requirements, such as at least 55 miles per gallon for trucks or sport utility vehicles, and at least 65 miles per gallon for other vehicles. The vehicle must be purchased after the enactment of this section, assembled in the United States by individuals under a collective bargaining agreement, have its original use begin with the taxpayer, and be primarily used by the taxpayer. The tax code provides credits for purchasing qualified passenger vehicles based on fuel economy requirements. The fuel economy must be at least 35 miles per gallon for trucks or sport utility vehicles, and at least 45 miles per gallon for other vehicles. The basis of the property for which the credit is allowed will be reduced by the amount of the credit. No credit is allowed for property used outside the United States. The tax code provides credits for purchasing qualified passenger vehicles based on fuel economy requirements, with the basis of the property reduced by the credit amount. No credit is allowed for property used outside the United States. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in subpart A. Section 25C allows for the purchase of fuel-efficient American-made passenger vehicles. The amendments apply to taxable years ending after the enactment of the Act. Section 4 addresses mass transit fare reductions during gas price spikes. The Secretary of Transportation may grant funds to mass transit systems to reduce passenger fares. The grants must be used for fare reductions that apply equally to all passengers. Mass transit systems include buses and commuter rails. Funding is authorized based on excess revenues from the previous fiscal year related to windfall profits on oil and petroleum products. The Secretary of Transportation may grant funds to mass transit systems for fare reductions that apply equally to all passengers. Funding is authorized based on excess revenues from the previous fiscal year related to windfall profits on oil and petroleum products, as well as the revenue cost for purchasing fuel-efficient American-made passenger vehicles. Amounts authorized remain available until expended. SEC. 5. REASONABLE PROFITS BOARD. The Reasonable Profits Board is established as an independent board to determine reasonable profits for the Internal Revenue Code. It consists of 3 members appointed by the President for a 3-year term, with no financial interests in relevant businesses. The Reasonable Profits Board, established independently, determines profits for the Internal Revenue Code. Board members are paid at a rate equal to the minimum annual rate of basic pay for level IV of the Executive Schedule and receive travel expenses. The Board appoints a Director with no financial interests in relevant businesses. The Director of the Reasonable Profits Board is paid at the rate of basic pay for level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Director can appoint additional personnel without following standard appointment procedures and may pay them accordingly. The Reasonable Profits Board can request personnel from federal departments, the Comptroller General can provide assistance, and the Board can hire experts or consultants through contracts. The Reasonable Profits Board has the authority to lease space and acquire personal property within available funds. Appropriations are authorized as necessary for this purpose.
